channel.title: How to make your source Linux compatible?
channel.description:
Hey MoparScape.
Is there a way to make your source/client ( I'm using Azure) compatible to run on Linux? Basically how do I run, edit, and play my server on a Linux computer, when the source is originally only compatible for Windows?

item.title: How to make your source Linux compatible?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

unless you’re using JNI or messing with Runtime.exec(…), Java is completely cross-platform compatible.

Read full topic
item.source: How to make your source Linux compatible?

item.title: How to make your source Linux compatible?
item.dc:creator: @TiVo TiVo
item.description:
@TiVo wrote:

I go to eclipses’ directory, type in that code, and I get this:

 sudo: setresuid(ROOT_UID, 1, ROOT_UID} Operation not permitted

It doesnt run if I simply try to run the eclipse file in the folder. Any ideas?

Bump.

Read full topic
item.source: How to make your source Linux compatible?

item.title: How to make your source Linux compatible?
item.dc:creator: @Native1 Native^
item.description:
@Native1 wrote:

Eclipse works. Install it by using.

sudo apt-get install eclipse

Read full topic
item.source: How to make your source Linux compatible?

item.title: How to make your source Linux compatible?
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

[quote=“TiVo, post:1, topic:429407”]Hey MoparScape.

Is there a way to make your source/client ( I’m using Azure) compatible to run on Linux? Basically how do I run, edit, and play my server on a Linux computer, when the source is originally only compatible for Windows?[/quote]

Java is cross platform. You should be able to run it on linux without any issues. You just have to use terminal to run the main class instead of a batch file

Read full topic
